repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - First, Second, Third, and
            Fourth Infrastructure Development Policy Loans Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, Third,
            and Fourth Infrastructure Development Policy Loans Project
            (IDPL) for Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            policy reforms are implemented and therefore driven by the
            middle level government officials across the range of
            ministries. Reforms should therefore incorporate the
            tactical and political sense of these key government
            counterparts when designing the pace and scope of a program.
            Where consensus is uncertain, a deliberation process along
            with modest expectations should be established up front to
            allow policy options to be explored and breakthroughs to
            emerge. To support such a process, constant dialogue between
            the Government and the Bank is fundamental and is best
            facilitated by a strong field presence across a wide range
            of sectors which views policy discussions as a natural part
            of ongoing support. The monitoring and evaluation (M&E)
            system for IDPL lacked in places, quantitative indicators,
            baseline data, strong targets and a system for monitoring
            and recalibration of variables. For the system to be a
            useful management tool for Government, it is important for
            outcomes to be monitored and attributed to design and
            implementation issues, so that the latter can receive
            attention. For this to occur, integration of the M&E
            framework with the results framework is needed so: (i)
            objectives are explicitly stated, (ii) associated outcomes
            are targeted with numerical indicators, (iii) policy actions
            are specified which will credibly influence the targeted
            indicators, and (iv) on-going calibration of policy changes,
            external changes and targeted indicators are carried out as
            part of Government functions to support implementation of a
            multi-year, multi-sector program of the complexity of the
            IDPL series.

9503435.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - First Infrastructure
            Development Policy Loan (IDPL)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Indonesia First Infrastructure
            Development Policy Loan (IDPL) is the first in a proposed
            series of programmatic IDPLs to support a carefully selected
            subset of Indonesia's broader reform agenda on
            infrastructure, focusing on: (i) central government
            infrastructure expenditures; (ii) sub-national government
            infrastructure spending; (iii) public-private partnerships;
            and (iv) cross-sector infrastructure support such as land
            acquisition, environment and procurement reform. This loan
            will build on and deepen the reforms undertaken by the
            Government of Indonesia as supported by other development partners.

Indonesia - First Infrastructure Development
